alert.note: Alert for Barry (Michigan) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued April 09 at 9:04PM EDT until April 10 at 5:00PM EDT by NWS Grand Rapids
info.description: ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Michigan... Grand River at Robinson Township affecting Ottawa County. Grand River at Grand Rapids affecting Kent County. Grand River at Lowell affecting Kent County. Grand River near Comstock Park affecting Kent County. ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in Michigan... Maple River at Maple Rapids affecting Clinton County. Thornapple River Near Caledonia affecting Kent County. Thornapple River Above Hastings affecting Barry County. For the Grand River...including Jackson, Eaton Rapids - USGS, Eaton Rapids, Dimondale, Lansing, Grand Ledge, Portland, Ionia, Lowell, Ada, Comstock Park, Grand Rapids, Eastmanville, Robinson Township... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Maple River...including Maple Rapids...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Thornapple River...including Hastings, Caledonia...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL TOMORROW AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Thornapple River Above Hastings. * WHEN...Until tomorrow afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 7.0 feet, Expect minor flooding of Tyden Park in Hastings, and homes upstream and downstream of Hastings. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 8:15 PM EDT Sunday the stage was 7.3 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 8:15 PM EDT Sunday was 7.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage late tonight and continue falling to 4.1 feet Sunday evening. - Flood stage is 7.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 7.3 feet on 06/30/2021. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Motorists should not attempt to drive around barricades or drive cars through flooded areas. Even 6 inches of fast-moving flood water can knock you off your feet and a depth of 2 feet will float your car. Never try to walk, swim, or drive through such swift water. If you come upon flood waters, stop, turn around and go another way. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov/grr.
